alert.note: Alert for Horry; Marion (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued September 02 at 8:41PM EDT until further notice by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina... Lumber River 1 SE Nichols affecting Marion, Dillon and Horry Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Lumber River Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County. Black River At Kingstree affecting Williamsburg County. Northeast Cape Fear River Near Burgaw affecting Pender County. Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Marion and Horry Counties. Waccamaw River At Conway affecting Horry County. For the Northeast Cape Fear River...including Burgaw...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Little Pee Dee River...including Galivants Ferry...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Waccamaw River...including Aiw At old Hwy 544 At Socastee, Conway, Above Conway, Freeland, Longs...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Black River...including Kingstree...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Flood waters will continue to rise in the Fork Retch community located near Nichols. Flood waters will begin to affect some homes at Fork Retch. Swampland flooding will increase. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM EDT Saturday the stage was 11.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 11.2 feet just after midnight tonight. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by Sunday afternoon.
